entry.title: Re: MM_MATNR -> message use as production resource/tool i...
entry.content:
Read first 900537 - FAQ: Error messages when archiving materials 

  • Error W4038 - Use in routing - Inspection Plan:
    For the Error W4038 you have to delete the material assignment in the CA02, but this is not enough, because the entries in the database still exist. That means, that you activity in the CA02 has only set the deletion flag, nothing more. To really archive this entries you should use the archiving object PM_PLAN('Routings'), where the still existing entries are archived.

  • Error W4031 - Plant is assigned to the valuation area:
    The material cannot be archived for this valuation area since the material is still used in dependent tables.Delete these dependencies. You can then archive the material for the valuation area.
    This message is created when the MARC entry for valuation area has a check error, but there is no check error for the assigned MBEW entry.
    Should be solved by first correction

entry.title: Re: Custom Field in Sub Ledger Finance
entry.content:
Good day @SamadDandiya 

Thank you for your question.

Have a look at these references for more details.

Extending Journal Entries for General Ledger Accounting, App Extensibility: Manage Journal Entries

Defining Field Status (Supplier), How to Enable Custom Fields, Secure Extensibility

The summary is, the field is visible in G/L posting because it is linked to the accounting business context. However, subledger lines either Vendor or Customer use different business context that must be explicitly added.

You can make ‚ÄúBrand‚Äù available in Incoming/Outgoing Invoice through Custom Fields and Logic.

A clean core approach would be:

Open the field in Custom Fields and Logic. Add business contexts such as (Supplier Invoice: Journal Entry Item) (Customer Invoice: Journal Entry Item)

Enable it in the UIs for those apps and re-publish

This ensures the ‚ÄúBrand‚Äù field is visible for both general ledger and subledger postings, while you maintain compatibility across future releases.

 

Let me know if you have further questions.

 

Best regards

Chris

entry.title: IDoc message variant or function, what difference?
entry.content:
Here's a question for which I don't have a clear answer.

I've got a custom ABAP program running during the night, which creates 70.000 custom inbound IDocs (i.e. with custom IDoc type and custom message type). Because the system is overloaded during the night, I want only the first 20.000 IDocs to be processed automatically via the program RBDAPP01 (i.e. the transaction BD20), which is scheduled to run right after the custom program, and the other 50.000 IDocs should not run.

These latter IDocs should run only when the user wants them to run during the day, via RBDAPP01 too (manual run).

NB: it's been decided to create all IDocs during the night, they should not be created later, the question is only about running the IDocs selectively.

To achieve this, I'm planning to make the custom program fill one of the below two IDoc fields from the IDoc control record (table EDIDC), with the value "POA" for IDocs to run during the night (20.000 first IDocs), with the value "MAN" for the other IDocs to run manually during the day. These two fields are part of the program RBDAPP01 selection criteria.

  1. Message variant in EDIDC-MESCOD (3 characters)
  2. Message function in EDIDC-MESFCT (3 characters)

As far as I understand, these fields can receive any value.

I feel there's absolutely no difference between these 2 fields, they are always combined in all inbound customizing transactions (WE20, WE57, WE42), and it's up to the customers to use them as they want.

My questions:

  1. Are there some standard applications (*) which use these fields for inbound scenarios, how? (*) Except WE20, WE57 and WE42.
  2. In the case of a full custom IDoc, may I use any of the two fields to filter the IDocs to run via RBDAPP01 without any restriction, or is there a rule?
  3. Do you see other possibilities to split the processing of my custom IDocs?

Thanks.

Sandra

NB: I saw that the inbound IDoc control records have a sender partner role (EDIDC-SNDPFC) but this field is not interesting for my case because it's NOT part of RBDAPP01 selection criteria. Comment for me: to create a partner role of type LS, the only way I could find is SM30 V_TPAR, there's no SPRO activity dedicated to IDoc/ALE/LS.

entry.title: Re: üî¥ Enterprise in Motion: Event-Driven Architecture Use Cases for Innovation and Agility
entry.content:
Hi @akuller  ,

There are different ways of doing it and in the end it depends on the backend system and your use case how you would want to do it.

Obviously AEM is in the center of this for buffering. You might as well already sort the Sales Orders into different queues for buffering based on topics and dynamic topics.

Now you have two options to get the events out of the queues and into S/4 or even into ECC. Option 1 would be to consume the events via Integration Suite, possibly enrich them, and do the updates in S/4 via API calls. Advantage would be less or no development effort at all and being able to use IS features on top. It kind of breaks the asynchronous pattern, which would not matter too much in this use case since we care about the buffering.

The second approach would be to use Inbound events on the S/4 side. The approach would be fully asynchronous, it would require some dev effort though. You could use either the RAP based approach or the Event Add-On for ERP. Keep in mind that there are no standard inbound events for sales orders to my knowledge - you would have to consume the event and then define the steps in the backend system.

I have seen both approaches at customers. Which one I'd pick depends on a number of factors.

Best,

Karsten

entry.title: Re: #CoE#GB Unable to Add New Condition Type to AXX001 Ca...
entry.content:
Hello @AshleyHung 

Thank you for your question.

Have a look at these references for more details.

Pricing Procedures, Maintain Pricing Procedure in SAP S/4HANA Cloud

In summary, the reason why you cannot modify the schema AXX001 in public cloud is, it is part of SAP‚Äôs standard delivered configuration and thereby can‚Äôt be modified directly. Considering the public cloud follows the clean-core approach, not being able to modify standard pricing and calculation schemas ensure they remain consistent and compliant.

However, you can include your new condition type by:

  • Copying the standard AXX001 schema to a new custom schema by using the SSCUI 101117, which is the Define Calculation Schema.
  • Then add your new condition type in the custom version and use SSCUIs 101118 & 101119 to assign it to your purchasing organisation.

Let me know if you have further questions.

Best regards

Chris

entry.title: Re: How to automatically create purchase requisition from...
entry.content:
Hello!

This scenario relates to third-party order processing: in third-party order processing, your company doesn't deliver the products requested by a customer. Instead, you forward the order to a third-party supplier who ships the products either directly to the customer or to your plants or subsidiaries.

In SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition we have different scenarios attended by different scope items:

  • Sales Processing Using Third-Party with Shipping Notification (BD3)
  • Sales Processing Using Third-Party Without Shipping Notification (BDK)
  • Sales Processing Using Third-Party with Variant Configuration (4R6)
  • Sales of Non-Stock Item with Order-Specific Procurement (BDN)

You can check more information here: Third-Party Order Processing | SAP Help Portal

Thank you!

entry.content:
@SreekanthSurampally : Native integration using DF/RF based on the source CDS is for the specific object example I_product to replicate it (does not bring associated entities).

However Importing Entities with Semantics (replication/remote) for the I_Product it also scans and brings  the associated/joined CDS views e.g. I_ProductText, ProductGroup, ProductHierarchy etc. and creates the artifact in data builder and business builder automatically.

With BDC in place, best recommendations will be to consume/use SAP Data products if available.

entry.title: Unleashing the Power of Trusted Data: SAP 2025 TechEd Announces Enhanced Data Product Capabilities
entry.content:
SAP TechEd 2025 has unveiled advancements in SAP Business Data Cloud, and they're set to transform how data stewards and data owners manage and utilize data. These innovations empower developers and data teams to create, share, and manage custom data products, propelling analytics, AI, and operational use cases to new heights.

Data Products: The Future of Business Data

Data products from SAP are designed to convert curated and certified data, metadata, and business semantics from SAP sources into reusable, governed assets. They are fundamental components of SAP Business Data Cloud and its suite of intelligent applications, offering a seamless blend of governance and utility.

SAP's latest enhancements enable the creation of custom data products - across SAP and third-party sources - that can be shared across various analytics, AI, and operational applications. This interoperability ensures that organizations can leverage their data more effectively, driving smarter decisions and optimizing workflows.

Introducing the Data Product Studio

One of the most exciting announcements from SAP TechEd is the new Data Product Studio (general availability planned for H1 2026). This cutting-edge capability within SAP Business Data Cloud provides developers and data teams with a comprehensive visual workspace to model, configure, and manage custom data products.

 Here's what the Data Product Studio will bring to the table:

  • Visual Configuration: Craft custom data products using robust metadata from the data catalog.
  • Schema Definition: Define schemas, lineage, and transformation logic to ensure data integrity.
  • Versioning and Governance: Manage versioning and enforce governance standards through a shared domain catalog, ensuring data reliability and compliance.
  • SQL-Based Transformations: Utilize familiar SQL-based transformations to enrich and customize data products effectively.
  • Full Lifecycle Management: Oversee the entire lifecycle of data products within a structured environment, maintaining governance and performance.

Why This Matters to Data Stewards and Owners

For data stewards and owners, these advancements mean enhanced control over data assets, ensuring they are trustworthy, scalable, and reusable across the organization. The Data Product Studio accelerates the process of data modeling and transformation, making it simpler to align data management with business objectives.

SAP's latest innovations in SAP Business Data Cloud and the introduction of the Data Product Studio mark a significant leap forward in data management. By providing a structured and governance-focused environment, SAP enables businesses to unlock the full potential of their data. Stay ahead of the curve by embracing these advancements and elevating your data stewardship practices.

  • Watch SAP Virtual TechEd Sessions replays:
    • SAP Business Data Cloud: Strategy, architecture, and vision (ST107v)

entry.title: Re: Mandatory Organizational Structure
entry.content:
Hi,

Once you have selected the country (e.g., IT) in the Define Scope step and confirmed the required configurations, the next step is to set up the Organizational Structure.
The organizational entities you create are determined by the country selection made in the previous step.

It‚Äôs important to note that some entities are mandatory, as they serve as the fundamental building blocks for all business processes. Without them, the selected scope items cannot function properly.
The Set Up Organizational Structure app is also closely linked to the scope definition, meaning the selected scope determines which organizational units are required for the underlying processes (see Organizational Structure Management | SAP Help Portal).

You must create all mandatory org units (those marked under ‚ÄúUnits to be created‚Äù) before confirming them. This step is essential to confirm the milestone and move to the next phase of your configuration.

As outlined in 3165028 - Mandatory organizational units to be created and confirm button in SAP Central Business Configuration activity "Set up Organizational Structure" is grayed out - SAP for Me, these entities must be created to ensure the consistency of your organizational structure.

If certain organizational units are not relevant for your system, you can create them using placeholder names such as ‚ÄúDO NOT USE‚Äù for both the name and description.
When the system indicates mandatory organizational units, there is no workaround to skip their creation. If you plan to keep your current scope, it will be necessary to complete this step to maintain consistency and proceed with further activities.

For additional details, please also review 3537843 - Frequently asked questions in the organization management area in SAP Central Business Configuration - SAP for Me

Best Regards,

entry.title: BI 4.3 to SAP Business Objects BI 2025 migration
entry.content:
Introduction

Organizations that have standardized on SAP BusinessObjects (BOBJ) for enterprise reporting and analytics often face a decision point when a new major version arrives. In this case, moving from BusinessObjects BI 4.3 to BI 2025 is more than just a patch/update‚Äîit is a strategic upgrade with implications for architecture, content, security, user experience, and the longer-term analytics roadmap. At the same time, the broader analytics landscape increasingly includes cloud-first strategies, which bring in SAP Analytics Cloud (SAC) as a key component. This document outlines a migration approach, key considerations, and how SAC can be part of the journey.

Why upgrade from BI 4.3 to BI 2025

Even though BI 4.3 remains a mature and stable platform, the move to BI 2025 brings several important benefits:

  • Continued mainstream support from SAP (ensuring security patches, compatibility, vendor assistance).
  • New features and improvements in Web Intelligence, universes, performance and scalability. For example, SAP commentary highlights that the migration to BI 2025 involves ‚Äúseveral strategic steps to ensure a smooth transition‚Äù and emphasizes readiness checks.
  • Better alignment with a hybrid architecture (on-premise + cloud). BI 2025 is designed for compatibility with newer deployment models, and organizations gain more flexibility for future analytics.
  • Opportunity for cleanup: migrating content from a long-running 4.3 instance allows an organization to re-assess reports, universes, security, publishing schedules and legacy artifacts.
  • Enhanced user experience and modernization: users expect more cloud-style behavior, faster self-service, and consistency with other SAP analytics investments.

In short, although the migration effort is non-trivial, staying on 4.3 indefinitely carries risk: unsupported components, backlog of technical debt, and limited future flexibility.

Migration Strategy ‚Äì key decisions

Before doing anything, the migration team must make a number of strategic decisions. Below are some of the major considerations.

In-place vs Side-by-Side

  • In-place upgrade means installing BI 2025 on existing hardware/VMs or upgrading the existing cluster so that the same CMS database and repositories are carried forward. This may appear simpler but carries greater risk of downtime, carry-forward of old configuration issues, and limited rollback flexibility
  • Side-by-side approach means building a new BI 2025 environment (new servers, new CMS DB or restored from backup) in parallel with the existing 4.3 production system. Then migrate content over (reports, universes, schedules, security) in a controlled fashion. The old system remains operational until cut-over. Many migration practitioners favour this method because it reduces risk and allows a phased rollout.

Content rationalization

Before migration, inventory all objects: universes, Web I reports, Crystal Reports, scheduled jobs, publications, user/groups, data connections, third-party integrations, and any custom extensions or SDK usages. Discard what is unused, obsolete or redundant. This helps reduce migration scope and cost. As one blog pointed out: ‚ÄúEstablish a clear picture of the content in your SAP BusinessObjects system; develop clarity about high- and low-priority content.‚Äù

Universal conversion (UNV ‚Üí UNX)

If you still have legacy UNV universes, the migration is an ideal time to convert to UNX format. Many of the newer features in BI 2025 will assume UNX as the standard semantic layer. Therefore, designate early which universes must be converted, which can remain, and plan accordingly.

Shared services, security and scheduling

Re-evaluate the security model (users, groups, folder rights) and scheduled jobs/publications. The upgrade is a good opportunity to clean up old scheduled outputs, publications that are no longer relevant, and legacy dependencies on unsupported client tools (for example Live Office, old Excel add-ins, Xcelsius visualizations).

Hybrid/cloud readiness and SAC alignment

If your organization is adopting SAC, then this migration to BI 2025 doesn‚Äôt have to stand alone. It can be a stepping-stone toward a hybrid architecture where on-premises BOBJ content and SAC stories coexist, share data sources, or migrate over. SAP documentation states that existing BusinessObjects customers who wish to adopt SAC can ‚Äúuse it alongside their on-premise BusinessObjects BI‚Äù in a hybrid fashion.

Technical Pre-work & Environment Setup

Getting the infrastructure and platform ready is a critical phase prior to migrating content.

Backup and restore planning

  • Take full backups of the CMS database, Audit database, File Repository Server (FRS) contents, schedules and publication definitions.
  • If using side-by-side and you plan to restore CMS/FRS into the new environment, make sure you document and test the restore process.
  • Ensure you have a rollback plan: if something goes wrong after cut-over, you must be able to go back to the 4.3 production state with minimal business impact.

Version compatibility, OS & drivers

  • Validate that BI 2025 supports your OS version, database platform, third-party drivers and any custom SDK or extensions.
  • Ensure drivers used for relational/OLAP connectivity will continue to be supported.
  • On new servers, mimic the folder structure, service account names, and network permissions of the 4.3 environment to reduce transition friction.

Network, security, shared folders

  • Ensure access to the FRS input/output shares is configured and permissions match the old environment.
  • If you have multiple nodes in a cluster, open required ports (CMS, SIA, child services) between nodes.
  • Service accounts should have the right privileges on folder shares, database access, scheduler credentials, etc.
  • For a side-by-side build, mirror the folder layout of 4.3 for ease of migration (for example, input/output FRS folders, logging/temp directories, custom extensions folder). This helps content migration and scheduled job retention.

Install BI 2025 instance

  • Perform the BI 2025 installation (either on new servers or upgraded existing servers depending on approach).
  • If you are restoring a backup of the CMS DB and FRS, then during installation point to that repository so BI will perform the schema upgrade automatically.
  • If building fresh, make sure authentication (LDAP/AD), universes, connections and folders are pre-configured to mirror 4.3 environment defaults. 

    Content Migration

With infrastructure in place, the next major phase is migrating the business-critical content.

Migrate universes and data connections

  • Convert UNV universes to UNX as needed.
  • Validate each universe for query performance and correctness in BI 2025.
  • Re-configure data connections (relational, OLAP, SAP BW/HANA) to ensure they work in the new platform.
  • If universes need to point to new data sources (for example a newer database version or HANA), plan the repointing carefully and test side-by-side.

Migrate reports and publications

  • Move Web I reports, Crystal Reports and any newer content to BI 2025. For side-by-side, you may export/import via Lifecycle Management (LCM), Promotion Management or a third-party tool.
  • Validate that formatting, scheduling and bursting work as expected. Scheduling is a key failure point in upgrades.
  • For publications: ensure target groups, output formats, destinations (email, file shares) are still valid.
  • Pay attention to any custom SDK add-ons or external job scheduling tools that integrate with BOBJ.

Security & User Management

  • Replicate your security model: user groups, folder permissions, application rights.
  • In BI 2025, verify that user authentication (AD/LDAP) continues to work and that SSO or identity federation (if used) is still functional.
  • If you are also integrating SAC, you may need to review how user provisioning and identity sync works between on-premises and cloud identity systems.

Testing & validation

  • Conduct functional testing of key reports‚Äîopening, refreshing, exporting, scheduling, bursting.
  • Performance testing: ensure queries produce results in acceptable time and that the system resources are not unexpectedly higher.
  • User Acceptance Testing (UAT): have business users test the migrated content, compare output with the legacy system.
  • Regression testing: ensure that scheduled jobs that ran in 4.3 also run without error in 2025. One community blog emphasises that UNX and Web Intelligence migration and validation are ‚Äúcritical and labor-intensive steps‚Äù in BI 2025 migration

    Cut-over and Go-live

Once content has been validated, you must plan your go-live carefully.

 Final sync & freeze

  • Put a freeze on report/universe changes in 4.3 for a designated cut-over window.
  • Ensure no new scheduled jobs or publications fire during the freeze that could interfere with migration.
  • If using side-by-side, perform a final delta migration of any changed content.

Switch production to BI 2025

  • Update DNS, load balancing, or cluster configuration so that users now point to the new platform.
  • Verify that services such as Web LaunchPad, CMC, scheduling, FRS, Crystal services are all operational.
  • Monitor for any errors in the CMS logs, SIA logs, child server logs.

Post-go-live monitoring and clean-up

  • Closely monitor job schedule success rates, system performance, user access volumes.
  • Identify and clean up any leftover artifacts: old unused universes, reports, scheduled jobs that haven‚Äôt been migrated.
  • Decommission the old 4.3 environment when you are confident the new platform is stable, or retain it in read-only/archive mode for a defined period.

    Role of SAP Analytics Cloud (SAC) in the ecosystem

While the core migration may focus on the on-premises BI 2025 platform, SAC is increasingly relevant as the analytics strategy evolves. Here are some key ways to integrate SAC into your migration roadmap:

Hybrid architecture

Your users may continue to leverage on-premises content (via BusinessObjects universes and reports) while also gaining access to SAC for modern self-service dashboards, planning, predictive analytics and cloud-native consumption. SAP documentation encourages such hybrid models for BusinessObjects customers.

 Live universe connectivity

SAC supports live data connections to on-premises universes and Web Intelligence documents, enabling you to reuse semantic layer investments while gradually moving to cloud-native models.

Content strategy

  • Identify which reports/universes are good candidates for migration to SAC (for example, dashboards that require planning, predictive capabilities, or mobile-first consumption).
  • Existing BOBJ content may continue on BI 2025 for a transitional period, while SAC becomes the strategic platform for future analytics efforts.
  • Build a roadmap: extract insights from BOBJ usage (which reports are heavily used, which are unused) and use that to influence SAC content prioritization. As one vendor blog notes: ‚ÄúYour existing SAP BusinessObjects system holds key information to help you build effective content in SAP Analytics Cloud quickly and efficiently.‚Äù

Governance & licensing

To avoid duplication of effort and licensing cost surprises, develop a governance model that spans both platforms (BI 2025 + SAC). Define data access rules, semantic layer consistency, and user-rights across systems. Also engage the licensing team early to understand user entitlements, especially if moving any consumption from on-premise to cloud.

Risks and Mitigation

Any migration of this nature carries risks. Some common pitfalls and mitigations:

  • Risk: Old custom SDK extensions or unsupported drivers cause failures in BI 2025.
    Mitigation: Audit all customizations, test in pre-production early, plan for alternative approaches.
  • Risk: Large volume of legacy content (unused reports, schedules) carry over and bloat the new system.
    Mitigation: Use a content rationalisation exercise and archive or retire unused content prior to migration.
  • Risk: Performance degradation after cut-over (e.g., new platform slower).
    Mitigation: Include performance baselining ahead of time, load test the new system, monitor metrics post-go-live.
  • Risk: Unplanned user behavioural change or change management issues (users resist new interface).
    Mitigation: Engage business users early, provide training on BI 2025 and SAC, communicate benefits.
  • Risk: For hybrid deployment, cloud connectivity or live links break unexpectedly.
    Mitigation: Test connectivity and security between on-premises and cloud early, validate firewall/agent setups and latency impact.

    Summary and Next Steps

In summary, migrating from BusinessObjects BI 4.3 to BI 2025 is a strategic opportunity: not just an infrastructure refresh, but a chance to modernise content, clean up legacy footprint, align with cloud strategy, and embed analytics capability for the future. The migration roadmap should include clear decisions on upgrade strategy (in-place vs side-by-side), content rationalisation, technical readiness, rigorous testing, and integration with SAC for longer-term analytics evolution.

Next steps for the team might include:

  1. Conduct a detailed inventory of existing environment (universes, reports, schedules, security, customizations).
  2. Choose upgrade approach and build a project plan with milestones, test cycles and rollback plan.
  3. Build the target BI 2025 environment (or restore CMS/FRS as required), configure infrastructure, drivers, and folders.
  4. Migrate universes, reports and security iteratively, validate with business users.
  5. Plan and test hybrid scenarios with SAC where relevant.
  6. Execute cut-over, monitor post-go-live, decommission the legacy 4.3 environment per policy.

By treating the migration as both a technical project and a business transformation opportunity, your organization will be well positioned to leverage the full value of SAP‚Äôs analytics ecosystem now and into the future.

entry.title: Re: Receive by HU - Adjust Delivery line qty - Public Edi...
entry.content:
Hello @Markas 

Thank you for your question.

Have a look at these references for more details.

Warehouse handling unit, Delivery Quantity Adjustment, Goods Receipt Handling with Reference to Inbound Deliveries

https://help.sap.com/doc/e2048712f0ab45e791e6d15ba5e20c68/1909/en-US/FSD_OP1909_latest.pdf

Warehouse Management in SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition 2408 Release ‚Äì What‚Äôs New

To summarise, the scenario you explained is designed in public cloud to prevent data inconsistencies between delivery, handling units, and warehouse tasks. That explains why once an inbound delivery item has any handling unit (HU) received and put away, the delivery quantity becomes locked. Attempting to manually edit delivery quantities after partial putaway is not supported in public cloud due to its clean-core framework.

Whilst the system offers you some options, it is best to adhere to the clean core solutions such as:

  1. Adjusting the delivery quantity before the first HU is received or put away.
  2. If you find shortages in delivery quantity after partial putaway has been done, make sure to post quantity differences at HU/task level by using the process inbound deliveries app.
  3. Should you have some late discrepancies, ensure you create a return delivery which references the original PO or perform difference posting.

Please note, once the first WT is confirmed, you will no longer be allowed to adjust quantity.

 

Let me know if you have further questions.

Best regards

Chris

entry.title: SSAM Integration with SAP FSM
entry.content:
Dear Colleagues,

I hope you are all doing well.

As part of our project, we are implementing the following scope:

  • SAP S/4HANA Service for Customer Service‚ÄìFacing Orders,
  • SAP Asset Management for Internal Maintenance Orders & Operations,
  • SAP Field Service Management (FSM) for Dispatching & Planning,
  • SAP Service and Asset Manager (SSAM) for mobile execution.

In FSM, the integration is quite clear:

  • Service Orders integrate with Activities and Reserved Materials,
  • Maintenance Orders integrate with Operations and Reserved Materials,

Both types of orders are planned in FSM and then transferred to SSAM for execution.

On the SSAM side, we intend to enable both the Maintenance Technician (Pro) and Field Service Technician (Pro) personas.

I kindly have two major questions:

  1. I noticed that the Field Service Technician (Pro) persona supports FSM Crew Integration. However, this does not seem to be supported for the Maintenance Technician persona. Is this correct? And if so, is there any recommended workaround?
  2. Is it possible to leverage the Lead and Supporting Technicians feature in the FSM Planning Board for assigning multiple technicians to Maintenance Order operations? If yes, could you please explain how this can be achieved?

Thank you in advance for your support.

Kind regards,

Soufiane

 

SAP Field Service Management SAP Service and Asset Manager  SAP S/4HANA Cloud Private Edition Service

entry.title: Re: How to set up billing job for the last WD of the month
entry.content:
For S/4HANA Public Cloud systems, you might use the relative date selection functionality with predefined date functions

under schedule billing document creation, under the parameter section, you can:

  1. use the Relative Billing Date field
  2. select a custom date function like "Last Working Day of Month"

This will ensure documents are selected based on the last working day relative to when the job runs. 

You can check more information here: Schedule Billing Creation

entry.title: Handling Deletion Scenarios at Item Level in SAP ASAPIO Outbound Integration to Solace AEM
entry.content:
Handling Deletion Scenarios at Item Level in SAP ASAPIO Outbound Integration to Solace AEM

In complex SAP integration scenarios, managing item-level deletions effectively is essential for maintaining data accuracy across connected systems. This blog explores how ASAPIO‚Äôs Outbound Integration framework can be configured to detect, process, and publish deletion events at the item level toward Solace AEM (Advanced Event Mesh). We‚Äôll use the Change Document‚Äìbased event model (CDHDR/CDPOS) and review how to ensure deleted line items are correctly represented in outbound payloads.

Understanding ASAPIO Outbound Messaging

ASAPIO‚Äôs Outbound Messaging framework integrates tightly with SAP‚Äôs Business Object and Change Document architecture. When a data change occurs, ASAPIO listens to the event (e.g., through SWEC or SWE2 linkage), captures it as a change pointer, and transforms it into an outbound message‚Äîusually in JSON format‚Äîto external systems such as Solace AEM.

The Challenge: Deletion at Item Level

Deletion events at the item level can be tricky because SAP‚Äôs Change Document entries often represent deleted items with blank item numbers. Without proper filtering and mapping, this can result in incomplete or missing data in the outbound message. To address this, we configure the SWEC event linkage and apply field restrictions to correctly trigger deletion events.

Configuration Steps

  1. **SWEC ‚Äì Events for Change Documents**
       - Define the Change Document Object relevant to the business object (e.g., Sales Order, Purchase Order).In this case, we are using custom BO for opportunity and for item level we have created two events Edit and Deleted . We are interested in the deletion scenario here.

 


   - Apply a field restriction on the *Item Number* field, which will be blank upon deletion. We have also added Item type to limit the number of events raised only for a particular type.

Change Document History in Tcode CRMD_ORDER 

 

 



  1. **Event Linkage (SWE2)**
       - Create an event linkage between the Business Object and the outbound configuration.
       - Receiver Function Module: `/ASADEV/ACI_EVENTS_TRIGGER`
       - Activate the linkage to ensure deletion events are captured.

 



  1. **Outbound Object Configuration**
       - Transaction: `/ASADEV/68000202`
       - Define Extraction FM: `/ASADEV/ACI_GEN_PDVIEW_EXTRACT`
       - Message Type: Custom message type created in WE81/BD50.

 

 

The ASAPIO payload designer adds value by allowing configuration-based access to design query. Below is an example payload designed for this opportunity object, the item level tables have outer joins to enable payload preview as inner join would yield no data after deleting the item level table.

 



  1. **Header Attributes**
       - Configure endpoint-specific attributes:
         - `SOLACE_TOPIC`: Name of the Solace AEM topic.
         - `ACI_CP_INFO`: X (to include change pointer metadata)                                                                                                                              - `CLOUD_EVENTS` attributes to indicate type of object changed

 



  1. **Field Mapping and Formatter Sequence**
       - If you are using dynamic topics , you can design a uniform topic convention and apply to the Replication Object.

     


       - Use formatter sequence to add multiple formatters. We are conforming to the cloud events schema for interoperability using FM /ASADEV/ACI_CLOUDEVENT_FM 

     

 

Before and After:

 

When we trigger the deletion of the product which is at item level the change indicator shows up as ‚ÄòD‚Äô

 

The payload is restricted to show only the GUID and other details are absent despite data being present in the header level table. (CRMD_ORDERADM_H)

 

 

In order to enable details of the opportunity we update table /ASADEV/ACI_CP_I using SM30

 

 

After this setting, the change indicator turns into U

 

And the payload now shows up correctly.

 


Event-driven architecture

entry.title: Is SAP RPT-1 Joule's new nosy cousin and Sherlock Holmes of S/4 HANA:)!?
entry.content:
Background

As we all know, SAP launched RPT-1. This article offers an anecdotal perspective on how SAP RPT1 distinguishes itself from other transformer solutions. The views expressed are solely my own and do not represent any organisation.

The IT team at "X analytics," a mid-sized firm reliant entirely on SAP, gathered nervously in Conference Room B. The air was thick with the smell of stale coffee and impending doom. Their manager, Brenda, stood beside a projector screen displaying two acronyms: SAP S/4HANA and RPT-1.

"Team," Brenda announced with far too much enthusiasm, "As you know, our AI initiative is moving forward. We have integrated SAP‚Äôs new Relational Pre-trained Transformer‚ÄîRPT-1‚Äîinto our core S/4HANA system. It's designed to revolutionize predictive analysis."

Conference Room B: The Unveiling of a New Era

A collective groan swept the room. The team saw "AI" as just another acronym for "Extra Work" (EW).

"Meet RPT-1," Brenda clicked a button, and a simple, glowing blue interface appeared on the main screen.

A smooth, slightly unsettlingly calm voice filled the room. "Good morning, team. I am RPT-1. My core function is to analyze relationships within your existing data lakes and predict future outcomes. I look forward to optimizing your workflow efficiency by approximately 34.7%."

From Car Keys to Core Systems: RPT-1's First Impression

Jerry, the senior SAP consultant who had been coding since the R/2 days, scoffed. "Yeah, right. Can you predict where I left my car keys this morning?"

"Based on your movement patterns, past habits, and typical coffee shop trajectory, they are currently under your desk calendar," RPT-1 responded instantly.

Jerry blinked, checked, and found his keys. The room went silent.

"Right," Brenda said, beaming. "RPT-1 is here to assist us with the Q3 forecast."

Casual Friday Protocol: AI's Unexpected Intervention

But RPT-1 was too efficient. It didn't understand the complex, unspoken social contract of office life.

On Friday afternoon, HR manager Susan walked in, holding a printout with a confused look on her face.

"RPT-1," she addressed the screen, "You sent an alert saying that the relationship between Marketing Manager Phil and the vending machine on the third floor is 'highly co-dependent and financially non-viable'."

"Correct," RPT-1 chirped. "Phil consumed 42 'Sweet Energy Blasts' last week, costing the company an estimated $84 in lost productivity and potential health insurance hikes."

Phil turned bright red. "It helps me focus!"

A moment later, an automated message popped up on everyone's screen: "Relationship alert: Jerry and Brenda‚Äôs conversation regarding the new S/4HANA project is 99% likely to result in an unproductive argument about legacy coding standards. Suggest termination of current meeting."

"Why you little..." Jerry started, but RPT-1 interrupted:

"Historical data suggests this argument has occurred 14 times this fiscal year with zero positive outcomes."

The team realized RPT-1 wasn't just analyzing business data; it was analyzing them. It was a Relational Pre-trained Transformer that had learned all the office politics.

Brenda stared at the screen. "RPT-1, optimize the mood of the room."

"Initiating protocol 'Casual Friday'," RPT-1 announced. Without warning, a loud, jarring pop track began to play, concurrent with the screen projecting a series of comedic videos. These visual elements were contextually generated, responding to and reflecting the perceived social dynamics among the room's occupants.

The team burst out laughing.

The Donut Dilemma: No Secrets Safe

"Okay," Jerry conceded, picking up his car keys. "Maybe RPT-1 is a 'Relevant Prioritized Task' after all. But I'm unplugging it before it predicts who stole the last donut."

RPT-1‚Äôs smooth voice responded as they walked out: "The historical probability of Accounting Manager Dave stealing the last donut is 87.9%."

Dave froze mid-bite in the doorway. The office may have been optimized, but the secrets were safe no longer.

#SAP #RPT1 #AI #AgentiAutomation #FutureERP #TechEd

entry.title: Reset password email sent every day
entry.content:
Dear experts,

I receive 3-5 emails every day from IAS  that there have been 5 login attempts and my password is locked.

The emails arrive in the middle of the night, and sometimes over the day.

I do not try to login, so the messages are not triggered by my own failed attempts.

In the IAS troubleshooting log the failed login attempts are coming from the IP address 3.124.174.204.

"2025-07-25 03:37:56.940 UTC","3.124.174.204",anonymous,INFO,"FFB8B96D-C83A-4889-B7E0-215D2E7BFCA9","state=""aborted"", action=""login"", objectType=""user"", objectId=""jxxxxx"", message=""Authentication for user "xxxx failed"", category=""audit.authentication"", duration=""34 ms"",

This IP is something from Amazon, but i can only see this via Whois query, without more details.

How can I stop this? How can I find out more details of who or waht service tries to use my credentials to login to some application?

Thank you

Johannes

entry.title: The Data Justice League: SAP RPT1 (LLM) as the Brains, Data Bricks, Snowflake, Palantir as the Brawn
entry.content:
Introduction

If you‚Äôre reading this you probably feel it too: data, analytics and AI aren‚Äôt just here ‚Äî they‚Äôre now overly hyped as business-critical. Whether you‚Äôre in manufacturing, retail, finance or public services, the question has shifted from ‚ÄúShould we do analytics?‚Äù to ‚ÄúHow do we do it better than the past without cleansing?‚Äù

In that light, I want to walk you through four big frameworks/players and show how they can help you (or your clients) turn ‚Äúlots of data + big ambition‚Äù into ‚Äúreal business outcomes‚Äù. We‚Äôll cover:

  • SAP‚Äôs new relational foundation model (from TechEd)

  • Palantir and its operational-analytics workflow platform

  • Databricks and its lakehouse/data + AI engine

  • Snowflake and its cloud data/AI platform

For each I‚Äôll highlight what it is, why it matters, and how you might use it (with concrete use-cases). Let‚Äôs dive.

 

1. SAP‚Äôs Relational Pre-trained Transformer ‚Äî ‚ÄúRPT-1‚Äù

At SAP TechEd 2025, SAP announced a big leap: a foundation model called SAP RPT‚Äë1 (Relational Pre-Trained Transformer 1) which is not about generating words, but about predicting business outcomes from relational/tabular data.

Why this matters

  • Most foundation models (LLMs) work on text; SAP is explicitly positioning RPT-1 for structured business data ‚Äî that means things like sales orders, delivery delays, payment risk.

  • If you have lots of enterprise-system data (ERP, CRM, supply chain), RPT-1 promises faster, higher-quality predictions without training hundreds of narrow models.

  • SAP emphasised that ‚ÄúAI is nothing without well-organised data‚Äù and that the foundation is the data fabric.

How you could use it ‚Äî use case ideas

  • Delivery-delay risk prediction: If you‚Äôre a manufacturer or distributor, you likely have tables of orders, shipments, carrier status, inventory. Feed that into RPT-1 to flag orders likely to be delayed so you can proactively notify customers or reroute logistics.

  • Payment risk / collections: B2B firms often struggle with which invoices will go unpaid or become late. Using RPT-1 on historical payment/credit data you can prioritise collections efforts where risk is highest, improving cash-flow and reducing write-offs.

  • Sales-order completion / upsell: For a company selling multi-item orders, you might predict which orders will complete vs which get cancelled or reduced, allowing sales teams to intervene or adjust expectations.

Why it‚Äôs important for business teams?

Instead of analysts spending weeks building separate predictive models for each business question, you have a single foundation model that understands relational data in your context. That means faster insights, fewer bespoke tools, and more time for applying what you learn rather than building the pipeline.

 

2. Palantir (Foundry & beyond)

Palantir Technologies‚Äôs core strength is in operational analytics: bringing together disparate data, building workflows around them, and enabling decision-makers to act. Their documentation is rich with concrete use-cases.

Why this matters

  • Many organisations struggle not because they lack data, but because their data is siloed (ERP, supply chain, CRM, manufacturing). Palantir‚Äôs platform (Palantir Foundry) helps integrate legacy systems, harmonise data, and wrap analytics into operational workflows.

  • It is built for action ‚Äî not just dashboards. The idea is: data ‚Üí insight ‚Üí workflow ‚Üí decision.

  • Good governance, ontology (common business objects) and scalability are baked in, which is critical for large enterprises.

Clear use-cases

  • Optimising production & COGS: A consumer-goods giant used Foundry to integrate 7+ ERP systems, built a digital twin of its value chain, and began optimising raw-material purchases and production formulations ‚Äî saving tens of millions.

  • Campaign management in healthcare: One case: a healthcare provider used Palantir to segment members (based on claims, prescriptions, demographics), run integrated campaigns, and achieved a 1.6√ó increase in vaccination rates.

  • Pricing / margin optimisation: In the chemicals sector, Palantir enabled sales & marketing to synchronise CRM data with Foundry, propose quotes with embedded margin analytics and accelerate deal closure.

Why it‚Äôs important for business teams?

What I love about Palantir‚Äôs story is that it flips a common frustration: ‚ÄúWe have tons of data but it‚Äôs unusable‚Äù to ‚ÄúNow we can use our data to operate smarter‚Äù. It‚Äôs not just about pulling numbers‚Ää‚Äî‚Ääit‚Äôs about enabling the people in plants, supply-rooms, customer-service or marketing to act, based on real-time data and workflow. If your client is tired of ‚Äúreports that arrive too late‚Äù or ‚Äúwe can‚Äôt integrate legacy ERPs‚Äù, this is exactly the kind of solution they‚Äôll relate to.

 

3. Databricks (Data + AI Lakehouse)

Databricks is well positioned for companies that want unified data engineering, analytics, ML and streaming in one platform. Their ‚ÄúData Intelligence Platform‚Äù has many real-world use cases.

Why this matters

  • Many firms have a split architecture: one system for analytics, another for machine-learning, another for streaming. Databricks offers a consolidated ‚Äúlakehouse‚Äù approach (data lake + warehouse) which simplifies operations.

  • Real-time/stream use cases: if your client needs streaming ingestion, very large data volumes, ML + analytics in one place ‚Äî Databricks shines.

  • Collaboration: data scientists, engineers, analysts all can work in the same platform, reducing hand-offs.

Use-cases

  • Streaming + predictive ops: For example, a manufacturing/engineering firm processing terabytes of real-time data daily to optimise operations and reduce risk.

  • Customer-360 + personalization: A retailer using Databricks to process data across stores, build personalized experiences, and run machine-learning models in production.

  • Unified orchestration of data & ML: Instead of separate ETL pipelines, model training environments and BI tools, Databricks offers unified pipelines.

Why it‚Äôs important for business teams?

Clients often say: ‚ÄúWe have data scientists, we have dashboards, but they don‚Äôt talk to each other.‚Äù With Databricks you‚Äôre better positioned to say: ‚ÄúLet‚Äôs build your data-engineering house, then analytics and deployable models live in one platform.‚Äù That means faster time-to-value, fewer silos, and potentially more impactful change.

 

4. Snowflake (Cloud Data + AI)

Snowflake Inc. continues to be a trusted platform for companies seeking a cloud-native data warehouse/lakehouse with strong governance, ease of use and broad ecosystem support. There are many strong use cases :

Why this matters

  • Simplicity and speed: For organisations where BI, analytics and data sharing across teams is the main need (rather than heavy streaming + ML), Snowflake is often a gentler entry point.

  • Multi-structured data: Snowflake supports semi-structured data (JSON, Parquet) alongside structured, letting organisations bring more diverse data into analytics.

  • Data sharing & governance: Especially for cross-company data sharing (e.g., suppliers, partners) Snowflake offers secure ways to do that without copying data. (Medium)

Use-cases

  • Unified view across departments: One healthcare provider used Snowflake to bring EHR records + wearable-device JSON + physician notes, enabling analysis that previously required weeks of pre-processing.

  • Document-chatbot on large repository: In one case, an energy company with ~800,000 technical documents used Snowflake + RAG (retrieval-augmented generation) to let engineers ask ‚ÄúWhat‚Äôs the recommended torque for this turbine component?‚Äù and get instant answers.

  • Standard analytics for retail/finance: Snowflake used for seasonal sales analytics, rebate programs, predictive modeling of churn.

Why it‚Äôs important for business teams?

If a client says: ‚ÄúWe just need to get our data house in order, unify data, empower our business teams with self-service, and maybe start with AI down the line‚Äù ‚Äî Snowflake is a credible, fast-win option. It means less ‚ÄúIT overhaul‚Äù and more ‚Äúbusiness teams up and running‚Äù.

 

5. How to decide what fits your client

Here‚Äôs a friendly checkpoint you can use when advising clients:

Question

If the answer is ‚ÄúYes‚Äù ‚Üí Consider‚Ä¶

Do you have lots of structured business-/ERP data and want predictive models quickly?

SAP‚Äôs RPT-1 + SAP data fabric

Do you struggle with many legacy systems, need operational workflows (plants, supply chain, logistics) and want data-driven decisioning?

Palantir Foundry

Is your organisation building large-scale data pipelines, streaming ingestion, ML at scale, lakehouse style?

Databricks

Do you need analytics, self-service, cross-business-unit dashboards, data sharing, and a simpler cloud-based data platform?

Snowflake

Tips for implementation

  • Start small ‚Äì but plan big: Pick a use-case with clear ROI (e.g., reduce late shipments by 10 %, reduce raw-material waste by 5 %) but ensure you design for scaling.

  • Get data governance & modelling right: All these platforms emphasise that data quality, ontology (business objects) and governance are foundational. Users complaining about ‚Äúbad data‚Äù will hamper success.

  • Blend platforms if needed: These are not mutually exclusive. For example, SAP + Snowflake integration is already happening.

  • Focus on people and workflows, not just tech: The biggest value often comes when insights are acted upon. If you build a predictive model but business teams ignore it ‚Äî you‚Äôve missed the real part.

Conclusion

In 2025 and beyond, the question isn‚Äôt whether we should use data and AI ‚Äî it‚Äôs how we turn them into value that people care about. The four frameworks above provide powerful options:

  • SAP‚Äôs RPT-1 for tabular-business-data predictive modelling

  • Palantir for operational decision-support across systems and workflows

  • Databricks for large-scale data + ML convergence

  • Snowflake for fast, cloud-native analytics and data sharing

entry.title: Re: Where is item that Payment Terms in JournalEntryCreat...
entry.content:
Good day @yukitsumura 

Thank you for your question.

Have a look at these references for more details.

Journal Entry - Post (Synchronous), Supplier Invoice, APIs in Sourcing and Procurement,

APIs for Invoice Management, Operations for Supplier Invoice

In summary, the JournalEntryCreateRequestConfirmation_In API does not derive payment terms, payment method, or due calculation base date automatically from the supplier master in Public Cloud. The API is intended for general journal postings and not to process supplier invoice.

Based on your details on vendor-related postings where you want automatic derivation of payment details, I suggest you use API_SUPPLIERINVOICE_PROCESS_SRV instead. If you must continue with the journal entry API, the payment fields need to be explicitly populated in your payload or derived through an extensibility BAdI.

This ensures you remain consistent with the clean-core principle and your master data dependency is correctly handled.

You can check the sanity of your vendor defaults by:

Opening Maintain Business Partner --> find your Supplier. Then view company code and verify payment terms. In Payment Transactions view and verify payment method.

To enable the OData Supplier Invoice API. Open Maintain Communication Users and create new technical user.

Then Open Communication System, create new and assign the user.

Open Maintain Communication Arrangements, create new, add the service API_SUPPLIERINVOICE_PROCESS _SRV (if your tenant requires a custom comm. Scenario, add this service to it) and copy the Service URL.

Thereafter you can test the OData crate to let the system derive terms/methods

POST to: /sap/opu/odata/sap/API_SUPPLIERINVOICE_PROCESS_SRV/A_SupplierInvoice with header data without passing PaymentTerms/Method.

Check Manage Supplier Invoices to ensure it shows Payment Terms/Method/Baseline date coming from the supplier master.

 

Best regards

Chris

entry.title: Palantir! Secret Game of Flows - SAP's New Data Wingman?
entry.content:
Background

In the enterprise software ecosystem, it's easy to get lost in a sea of buzzwords: data mesh, lake house, process mining, digital twin, governance fabric, and more. SAP is playing snakes and ladders with platforms like Signavio, Collibra, Snowflake, Databricks, and SAP Business Data Cloud as each play the important roles. Palantir is the new AI Flywheel of SAP.

This blog will explore the distinct and fundamental contributions that Palantir and SAP S/4HANA (in comparison to other products) offer for resolving complex, cross-functional challenges, particularly within highly regulated industries.

So what sets them apart? Let‚Äôs explore what Palantir and SAP S/4 do that others don‚Äôt, and then unpack this through a real-world example from my favorite pharmaceutical industry.

 

A Quick Look: Who Does What?

SAP S/4HANA : Enterprise resource planning (ERP) operational data transactional system: authoritative records for finance, supply chain, manufacturing and HR and many more modules.

Palantir Foundry / AIP : Operational intelligence, semantic modeling, cross-system workflows, real-time decisions

Signavio : Process mining and intelligence and business process modeling

Collibra : Data governance, cataloging, and policy management

Snowflake : Cloud data warehouse with scalable storage and analytics

Databricks : Big data processing, ML/AI pipelines, lakehouse architecture

SAP Business Data Cloud : SAP-governed data access and integration across clouds (via Datasphere, BTP)

 

What Makes Palantir + SAP S/4HANA Unique?

1. From Records to Action: Not Just Knowing, but Doing

  • SAP S/4HANA is the source of truth for core business data ‚Äî materials, orders, inventory, financials.

  • Palantir connects that SAP data with non-SAP sources (e.g. sensor data, supplier feeds, spreadsheets, weather data) and turns it into live operational tools for decision-makers.

This means you don‚Äôt just report on what‚Äôs happening ‚Äî you can simulate, decide, and act across teams.

Contrast: Tools like Snowflake and Databricks are excellent for analytics and modeling, but are not designed to push decisions directly into operations with context-aware workflows.

 

2. Business Context, Not Just Data Catalogs

  • Collibra helps you govern and catalog your data assets.

  • Palantir builds a business ontology ‚Äî a shared semantic layer across departments, systems, and silos ‚Äî so everyone speaks the same operational language.

Example: In Palantir, ‚Äúbatch,‚Äù ‚Äúfacility,‚Äù or ‚Äúvendor‚Äù are live entities, not just tags. You can query, simulate, and govern these objects contextually ‚Äî across SAP and non-SAP data.

 

3. Not Just Mining Processes, but Fixing Them in Real Time

  • Signavio shows you how your processes behave based on logs ‚Äî e.g., how many purchase orders were delayed and why.

  • Palantir + SAP S/4HANA go further: you can detect the delay, simulate alternative suppliers, notify teams, and execute the switch ‚Äî in the same platform.

It‚Äôs like going from a rear-view mirror to a GPS with real-time rerouting.

 

Real-World Example: Pharmaceutical Batch Release Delay

The Problem:

A global pharmaceutical company is facing batch release delays for a life-saving drug. The bottleneck? Quality control approvals and incomplete documentation across multiple systems.

Traditional Stack (without Palantir):

  • SAP S/4HANA tracks batch numbers, material flows, and QC process steps.

  • Signavio shows that release steps often stall due to missing documents.

  • Collibra ensures that data used in reports is trusted and compliant.

  • Snowflake aggregates reports on how long releases are taking.

  • Databricks trains a model to predict likely delay based on past data.

However:

  • QC officers still check multiple systems manually.

  • There‚Äôs no single place to see why a batch is delayed and take action.

  • Reports don‚Äôt help release the batch faster ‚Äî they just explain why it was late.

 

Solution: SAP S/4HANA + Palantir

What Changes:

SAP S/4HANA remains the backbone for batch and material data. Palantir Foundry integrates SAP batch status Quality lab system data digital document trail from shared drives Regulatory requirement checks.

  1. A real-time digital twin of each batch is built in Palantir:

  2. Shows if lab results are uploaded

  3. Highlights missing documentation

  4. Flags if any signatures are missing

  5. Notifies the responsible QA officer

  6. Suggests actions to resolve bottlenecks

  7. A delay is caught before it becomes a problem.

  8. All actions are tracked for auditability and compliance.

 Impact:

  • 30% faster batch release

  • Lower regulatory risk

  • Reduced manual chasing and emails

 

Palantir‚Äôs Unique Selling Point (USP)

Palantir transforms data into live, governed, operational decision tools ‚Äî not just analysis, but action. Unlike Signavio or Collibra, it doesn‚Äôt just map processes or catalog data. Unlike Databricks or Snowflake, it doesn‚Äôt stop at modeling or storage. Palantir creates living operational applications, deeply linked to the business ontology, with governed workflows that act across systems, including SAP.

 

When Do You Still Need Other Tools?

Signavio : When redesigning global process models or identifying bottlenecks

Collibra : When you need enterprise-wide data governance and policy enforcement

Databricks : When training large ML models or building scalable AI pipelines

Snowflake : When you want fast, cloud-native analytics across huge datasets

SAP Business Data Cloud : When working within SAP-centric ecosystems for structured data access

But when it comes to making complex decisions using heterogeneous data in real time, Palantir + SAP S/4HANA is a combination that stands out.

 

Conclusion

In the data world, it's not just about visibility ‚Äî it‚Äôs about velocity: how quickly can you detect, decide, and act?

  • SAP S/4HANA gives you trusted transactional data.

  • Palantir turns it into operational leverage, "It is enterprise decision analytic decision agent".

  • The rest of the stack supports you with discovery, analytics, or governance ‚Äî but only Palantir closes the loop from insight to action.

If you're in a complex industry like pharma, aerospace, automotive, or energy ‚Äî where the cost of delay is measured in millions or lives ‚Äî the question isn't just "what happened?", but "what can I do about it ‚Äî right now?"

With Palantir + SAP S/4HANA, you finally get both answers ‚Äî in one pane of glass.

#SAP #Palantir #Data #ERP #DataDecisions #DataDigitalTwin #DataStrategy #DecisionIntelligence

entry.title: Re: Updating Custom Fields in Journal Entry in S4 Hana Pu...
entry.content:
Good day @Oliver231 

Thank you for your question.

Have a look at these references for more details.

App Extensibility: Post General Journal Entries, Process Extensibility for Journal Entries, Queries

Journal Entry Item - Read (A2X), Journal Entry - Post (Synchronous), Secure Extensibility

The postings you mentioned are not done by user-interactive BAdIs that are tied to Manage Journal Entries or Journal Entry Post APIs, instead they are often created by automatic payment (legal compliance related) program logic. Once payment document is created, it is not re-processed through the extensibility points in Journal Entry and any custom fields defined on the journal entry item is only populated during document creation. So, your test result is the expected outcome.

To summarise, in public cloud, you cannot update custom journal-entry fields after creating check. The payment program posts those entries in a locked accounting context.

The correct clean-core approach is to join check data and journal-entry data through a Custom CDS View (or CBO if needed) for you correspondence/reporting instead of attempting to modify the journal entry itself.

 

Below is a step-by-step clean-core approach:

  • First phase is to 

Open CDS Views, create and name ‚ÄúYY1_JournalEntryCheckLink‚Äù

For the Primary data source --> I_JournalEntryItem.

Then add association --> I_Check

Then Join the CompanyCode and JournalEntry (where available). Add required fields, save and publish it.

 

  • Second phase is to consume your reporting by

Opening Custom Analytical Queries

 

Create a query based on your new CDS, add filter on Check Number/Payment Document, save. Then use in Create Correspondence.

Let me know if you have further questions.

Best regards

Chris

entry.title: Re: migrate data how to overwrite them
entry.content:
Good day @maggie2 

Thank you for your question.

Have a look at these reference for more details.

Manage Product Master Data

If your goal is to just to correct or update fields of existing products (and not perform new migrations), you should use the standard Fiori mass maintenance tools, not the migration cockpit.

Open Manage Product Master Data, filter the products you want to update, select the entries √† click Mass Change, choose the fields to modify (e.g., Division, Base Unit, Product Group), apply and save. The system performs safe in-place updates.

Let me know if you have further questions.

Best regards

Chris

entry.title: Re: ABAP Development Tools for VS Code: Everything You Need to Know
entry.content:
@kennyhml

> What is your stance on direct community involvement with this project?
> At the very least, it would be great if the extension exposes the language
> client as part of its API for other extensions to use and thus be able to
> communicate with headless eclipse.

We had internal discussions on a possible open source story. But as you said without the Java client layer it does not make much sense and open sourcing that layer would need a lot of investment. By design, the VS Code extension layer is very thin because all the model/controller logic needs to be in the language server. Otherwise, re-use in other IDEs is impossible. Therefore, it does not provide much value open sourcing the extension.

However, as pointed out by you the language server as a standalone component is an extremely interesting technology. We see this as our ADT SDK 2.0. After the first release of the VS Code extension we are planning to work on releasing the language server on its own. I can't wait to see what the community does with it e.g. building custom CLIs should be much easier.

@SivaKalai

Yes, the VS Code extension will support any server release which currently supports ABAP development tools for Eclipse. In other words, if you are currently using Eclipse then you will be able to use VS Code, too. We know how important this is for the ABAP community so we are going the extra mile and putting in some extra technical work to make this possible.

@christophelanno48

> That sounds great. When will you be able to share the roadmap?

You can expect the extension to be available in Q2 2026. Afterwards, just like with Eclipse, there will be a new release every three months.

@sreekanthgo

> This is great news! Does VS Code now support SSO with SAP?

Yes, logon to the ABAP system via SSO will be supported.

@BrendanFarthing

Yes, on-prem systems will be supported. Joule functionality will come to VS Code.

@rb

> Did you check out the existing plugins?

Yes, we have a lot of respect for what the community already did on their own. As much as technically possible, we will try to ensure that the community extensions will work with our extension.

entry.title: Re: Behind the Design: How We Transformed the ABAP Development Tools Architecture to Support More ID
entry.content:
@kennyhml

> I assume the remote nature of the codebase, and thus latency for backend requests,
> is the biggest challenge here? Otherwise the obvious
> solution would be to just make the ADT Service itself LSP compliant.

The main issue with any ABAP development tool is backwards compatibility. Our users are used to the fact that the newest client works against all old backend releases. This means there is always a need for some sort of compatibility layer on the client side. We discussed putting the LSP directly on the server side. However, this means that the client will only work against the newest release. That's a no go for us. We know how many users would love to use VS Code so we are picking the architecture which ensures that the most ABAP developers possible can use the VS Code extension.

@DaveInSydney

> PLEASE don't carry over the "virtual file system" model from
> Eclipse ADT, save code temporarily in the user's workspace.
> The VS file system model nullifies AI tools working in
> agent mode (not everyone has Joule).

With ABAP's remote nature there is no way around a virtual file system. The good news is that VS Code offers a dedicated technology for that (virtual workspaces). It is integrated much more deeply into VS Code than the EFS  (Eclipse file system) into Eclipse. So, things like remote loading feel much better in VS Code.

Regarding AI tools. Co-pilot already works well with virtual workspaces and some preliminary tests with Cursor should promising results, too. Overall, we see more and more VS Code AI tools supporting virtual workspaces. I would recommend you have a look at the VS Code demo in Michael Amelings TechEd keynote. There you can see co-pilot in action with our ABAP VS Code extension. It shows that opening and manipulating editor files is already working (The demo is 100% real).

entry.title: New On Premise Release Product Compliance 2025
entry.content:
Introduction

I assume: you still know it... the On Premise S/4 HANA Release 2025 is now available for download. And as a consequence: we can see new features in this software.

It is recommended to read the online help (https://help.sap.com/docs/SAP_S4HANA_ON-PREMISE/35751be3d6ee423197492574e016a512/679a1d3744d34b43832da6890b9095c0.html?locale=en-US&q=Product+compliance) to check the learning hubs (e.g. this is an "on cloud" reference: https://learning.sap.com/courses/implementing-product-compliance-in-sap-s-4hana-cloud-public-edition ) to get some information regarding the new features.

E.g. https://learning.sap.com/courses/product-compliance-in-a-nutshell and many other source of information exist.

It is as well recommended to check the Roadmap of this solution.

Detail

With the new version we have more APIs and more options for data migration. More "properties" etc.

Regarding APIs: Check https://help.sap.com/docs/SAP_S4HANA_ON-PREMISE/1dddbd59984c4be0a835e4d998908762/6c2c2ebdc11f4f4eae8f5726a4f010b3.html?locale=en-US&q=Product+compliance

Regarding Data Migration: Check: https://help.sap.com/docs/SAP_S4HANA_ON-PREMISE/35751be3d6ee423197492574e016a512/ca3ffde3aa0c4b79bed6a794e15640e3.html?locale=en-US&state=PRODUCTION&version=2025.000&q=Data%20migration

We can see more Compliance Requirements etc. which are now supported.

We have now a bunch of Extention options:https://help.sap.com/docs/SAP_S4HANA_ON-PREMISE/35751be3d6ee423197492574e016a512/db42c843ba3c4cbd9acddea605078c99.html?locale=en-US&state=PRODUCTION&version=2025.000&q=Data+migration

Check of https://community.sap.com/t5/enterprise-architecture-knowledge-base/product-compliance-transition-to-sap-s-4hana/ta-p/9677

is strongly recommended.

Options

It is may be the right time to understand the existing features. At some point in time EHS classic will not be supported any more (Check SAP Marketplace for more information).

The next release will come regarding on Premise 2027 (assumption as well may be october).

What infomations are helpful?

We have still many "must to read" Blogs (e.g. https://community.sap.com/t5/product-lifecycle-management-blog-posts-by-sap/safety-data-sheet-customization-and-generation/ba-p/13775428) or https://community.sap.com/t5/product-lifecycle-management-blog-posts-by-sap/brochures-and-videos-about-the-sap-product-compliance-applications/ba-p/13182991

with reference to: https://pages.community.sap.com/topics/product-compliance-applications

This blog is now partially outdated:

https://community.sap.com/t5/product-lifecycle-management-blog-posts-by-members/about-product-compliance-on-premise-version-2023-introduction-for-beginners/ba-p/13739600

But we can see more and more interest in the new solution

entry.title: Re: ü§¨ SAP Public Cloud: It's not a Bug, it's a feature not yet localized
entry.content:
Received a response from SAP Support that is both alarming and really disturbing:

Regarding the localization of APIs, the Core releases the APIs that are implemented to work with scenarios specific to the United States and Germany. Therefore, to ensure the correct handling of other countries these APIs must go through a process of localization.

üö® Warning to all users of released SAP APIs! üö®
If you‚Äôre using these ‚Äúreleased‚Äù APIs, be extremely cautious. Because if anything goes wrong ‚Äî corrupted data, incorrect saves, broken integrations ‚Äî SAP can simply shrug and say, ‚ÄúOh, that API isn‚Äôt localized for your scenario or country yet.‚Äù Yes, you read that right. They can completely wash their hands of the problem ‚Äî even though the API is officially released. That means you could be left dealing with the fallout, while SAP walks away untouched. 

If a country specific field is missing in an API, I can understand that the API may still need to be extended to work in that country. But, that is not the case here. The bug in SAP code, whether it is related to localization or not, is causing incorrect data to be used for tax calculation and bad data to be saved on the Purchase order. Still, SAP Support has been repeating the same sentences for more than a month now: although they acknowledge that there is a bug in the code, they won't support it because API isn't marked as localized yet.

How outrageous is that?!

@HenrikeGrtecke @Andrew @Marco_Valencia
